newsitem.title: NORWAY: FOCUS-Kvaerner wins $1 billion cruise ship order.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Kvaerner wins $1 billion cruise ship order.

text.p: Norwegian shipbuilder and engineering group Kvaerner ASA said on Friday it had won a $1 billion order to build two 3,100-passenger cruise liners, the world's largest.
The company said it was its biggest ever shipbuilding contract.
Kvaerner said Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines Ltd had ordered the vessels, which will each have a gross tonnage of 130,000 tonnes and a passenger capacity of 3,100.
They will be more than twice the size of the Queen Elizabeth 2, the flagship of Kvaerner's passenger shipping division Cunard.
The largest passenger vessels currently under construction are between 105,000 and 110,000 gross tonnes.

Market speculation over the deal boosted Kvaerner's A share eight crowns on Thursday. The stock rose a further 13 crowns to a high of 273 crowns following the announcement before settling back to 267.50 crowns at 1246 GMT.
The B share was eight crowns higher at 246.50 crowns.

The ships will be built at the group's Kvaerner Masa-Yards in Turku, Finland. Temporary yard subsidiaries in Finland made it possible for Kvaerner Masa-Yards to be competitive against other European and Japanese yards, the company said.
"This is very good news for Kvaerner and reinforces the company's position as the the leading shipbuilder in the world," said company spokesman Paul Emberley.

Shipbuilding is Kvaerner's most profitable division and booked a pre-tax profit of 750 million crowns ($117 million) in the first nine months of 1996, almost 90 percent of the company's total result for period. ($1=6.409 Norwegian Crown)
